docs.lead_paragraph: Julian Adams never gave up on the cancer drug he helped to invent, even as it passed from company to company. He defied the skeptics who said it would never work. He persuaded nonprofit foundations and the government to pay for clinical trials when the companies he worked for could not. That drug, now known as Velcade and owned by Millennium Pharmaceuticals, was approved late today as a treatment for multiple myeloma, an often fatal cancer of the bone marrow.

headline.main: After a Long Struggle, Cancer Drug Wins Approval

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves Millennium Pharmaceuticals' drug Velcade as treatment for multiple myeloma, often fatal cancer of bone marrow; drug is expected to eventually to provide hundreds of millions of dollars in annual sales; is expected to cost about $20,000 for typical course of treatment; drug's inventor Julian Adams comments; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Julian Adams never gave up on the cancer drug he helped to invent, even as it passed from company to company. He defied the skeptics who said it would never work. He persuaded nonprofit foundations and the government to pay for clinical trials when...

docs.lead_paragraph: It's the early 21st century, and a tremor at the San Andreas Fault has devastated nuclear power plants in California. War and environmental havoc have caused famine and infertility throughout the United States. Right-wing Christian fanatics have assassinated the president and the Congress, reconstituting the nation as a male-controlled totalitarian state called Gilead in which women are deprived of all rights. Some of those still able to breed are enslaved as handmaids, after the biblical story of Jacob and Rachel, and forced to copulate with high-ranking commanders in degrading threesomes involving the commanders' barren wives. Margaret Atwood fans will recognize the plot of her apocalyptic 1984 novel, ''The Handmaid's Tale,'' a book both derided as a preposterous polemic and devoured as a chilling fantasy that explored the implications of fundamentalism from the Moral Majority to the Taliban.

headline.main: Eerie Echo Of Present In Futurist Fantasy

docs.abstract: Anthony Tommasini reviews Minnesota Opera production of Poul Ruders's The Handmaid's Tale, opera based on Margaret Atwood's novel; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a sad fact of life that, no matter how sincere one's philanthropic intentions may be, not everyone can be Ted Turner. That includes Lois W. Abraham. Last July, when Ms. Abraham learned that the Bush Administration was pulling back on $34 million in financial support to the United Nations Population Fund, she wanted to do something about it.

headline.main: U.N. Population Agency Recoups Some Lost Aid

docs.abstract: Citizens act to raise money for United Nations Population Fund after Bush administration decides to withhold entire US annual contribution to fund, $34 million, on ground fund aids Chinese government agencies that it says practice such population controls as coercive abortions and involuntary sterilization; fund denies such support and cites State Department fact-finding missing that found no evidence it supports such programs; photo of two organizers of fund-raising, Lois W Abraham and Jane K Roberts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To ignore a couple of time-honored writerly rules of thumb -- write what you know; show, don't tell -- takes nerve. To do so without showboating or proclaiming yourself a literary rebel takes self-possession. And to create vital, persuasive fiction while you're at it takes something else -- talent, obviously, and that rare quality readers long for and seldom find in an author: authority. Maile Meloy has it in spades. Somehow she pulls off what never quite seemed possible before: combining the meticulous realism of domestic fiction with the witchery of a natural-born storyteller. In her first novel, ''Liars and Saints,'' which will be published June 17, Meloy follows four tangled generations of the Santerre family, French Canadian Catholics who settle in Southern California during World War II. That sounds like a saga, yet the book is only 260 pages long -- and yet again you don't feel you've missed a thing. The things you haven't missed include life on an aircraft carrier in the war's Pacific theater, dance lessons at a Catholic girls' school, illicit sex leading to an illegitimate pregnancy, the Beatles, smoking pot in Hawaii, the Kennedy assassination, miscarriage, light bondage, a couple of cross-country road trips, political campaigns, divorce, incest (sort of), another illegitimate pregnancy, cancer, same-sex romance, a toothless old man who claims he can control reality with his mind, improbable reunions, apostasy and murder.

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: Page Turner; Maile Meloy, writer An Author With Authority

docs.abstract: Maile Meloy, whose first novel will be published in June, is among impressive and versatile group of young writers who have emerged from Master of Fine Arts program at Univ of California, Irving; group includes Michael Chabon, Alice Sebold, Glen David Gold, Aimee Bender and David Benioff; photo

docs.lead_paragraph: Clothing Sale for Lighthouse WEDNESDAY -- A preview of Lighthouse International's annual Posh sale of new and used designer clothing and accessories, at 110 East 60th Street, will raise money for the organization's programs for people who are blind and visually impaired. The evening begins at 6 with cocktails, hors d'oeuvres and the shopping. Tickets, $100, from (212)821-9445. The sale opens to the public on Thursday and concludes on Saturday, with admission at $10.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dates are subject to change. Aug. 1 AMERICAN WEDDING -- The gang from ''American Pie'' has done high school and college, and now Jim (Jason Biggs) and Michelle (Alyson Hannigan) are getting married. So there are all the comic opportunities of bridesmaids, bachelor-party strippers and the dying grandmother who is trying to hang on until the ceremony. Eugene Levy and Seann William Scott are back too. Adam Herz, who wrote the original movie's screenplay, wrote this one, but there's a new director, Jesse Dylan (son of Bob), who made his directorial debut two years ago with ''How High,'' a film in which most everybody did get stoned. A related article is on Page 11. AND NOW LADIES AND GENTLEMEN -- Jeremy Irons plays a British jewel thief who makes an emergency yacht landing near Morocco. Patricia Kass is a nightclub singer who has left Paris, and a romance, behind to accept an engagement in Morocco. They meet, and things would be going well if it weren't for the strange blackouts Mr. Irons's character has. Claude Lelouch (who, of course, made ''A Man and a Woman'' 37 years ago) is the director of this romantic thriller, which was the closing-night feature at the Cannes Film Festival last year.

docs.lead_paragraph: I'VE been in many different situations on film,'' said Luis Guzmán, nursing a saltless margarita in the lounge of an upscale hotel here. ''But I've always had this comic edge to myself.'' Dressed in jeans and a leather jacket over a T-shirt adorned with the image of one of his heroes, and countrymen, the Pittsburgh Pirates star Roberto Clemente, Mr. Guzmán, who was born in Puerto Rico and moved to New York City with his family as an infant, was in town to attend casting sessions for ''Luis.'' In this Fox sitcom pilot set in Spanish Harlem he stars as a doughnut-shop owner who is frequently at odds with his ex-wife and grown daughter.

headline.main: Gang Member No. 22 to Sitcom Dad

docs.abstract: Juan Morales interview with Luis Guzman, once considered menacing character actor, who has found new success in comedy roles in film and on TV; traces his career; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fertility clinics in the United States have accumulated some 400,000 frozen human embryos, about twice the number estimated, since 1986 when the in vitro fertilization procedure began, the first official inventory has found. The calculation is likely to influence the debate over human embryonic stem cells, which are derived from surplus embryos.

headline.main: Clinics Hold More Embryos Than Had Been Thought

docs.abstract: Survey finds US fertility clinics have accumulated some 400,000 frozen human embryos, about twice earlier estimates, since in vitro fertilizations began in 1986; many couples have surplus embryos frozen because of procedure's difficulties and US, unlike Britain, sets no limit on storage time; ethical implications discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the battle over legislation, there is no weapon as powerful as a victim. For four years, the Unborn Victims of Violence Act, a bill that would make it a federal crime to kill or harm a fetus, has languished in Congress. Now the killing of Laci Peterson, eight months pregnant with a son she had planned to name Conner, has greatly improved the legislation's prospects, Democrats and Republicans alike say.

headline.main: Washington Talk; From CNN to Congress, Legislation by Anecdote

docs.abstract: Laci Peterson case in California gives new impetus to Unborn Victims of Violence Act, which would make it federal crime to kill or harm fetus, and her family wants bill, which has been in Congress for four years, renamed Laci and Conner's Law, after her and unborn son who died with her; bill would not apply to prosecution of Scott Peterson, Laci's husband, who has been charged with double murder under state law, and would apply only to federal crimes, like those on military bases; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: She does not have the name recognition of a Brooke Astor or a Sanford I. Weill. But Sheila C. Johnson has been making a philanthropic mark in the elite horse country of Virginia, where she lives; in Washington, where she lived for many years; and, most recently, in New York, which she visits about twice a month. A co-founder of Black Entertainment Television and one of the wealthiest black women in the United States, Ms. Johnson is reshaping her life after the breakup of her 33-year marriage to Robert L. Johnson. In 2000, the Johnsons sold their company, BET Holdings, to Viacom for $2.3 billion in stock, splitting $1.5 billion of the proceeds, Ms. Johnson said.

headline.main: Philanthropy Her Own Way; As BET Co-Founder Reshapes Her Life, Serendipity Sneaks In

docs.abstract: Profile of Sheila C Johnson, co-founder of Black Entertainment Television and one of wealthiest black women in America; she is reshaping her life after breakup of her 33-year marriage to Robert L Johnson; in 2000, Johnsons sold their company, BET Holdings, to Viacom for $2.3 billion in stock, splitting $1.5 billion of proceeds; she has donated millions of dollars to variety of institutions; photo (L)
